name: 17-methyl-21-phenylpregnan-3-yl acetate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3559

name: 17-methyl-21-phenylpregnan-3-yl acetate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3559
Reason:
To predict the melting point of 17-methyl-21-phenylpregnan-3-yl acetate, we look at a basic steroidal scaffold and then account for the modifications. A simple pregnane skeleton would have a much lower melting point due to its flexible nature. For instance, progesterone, a related steroid, has a melting point of about 128°C. Each functional group contributes to the rigidity, molecular weight, and intermolecular interactions that influence melting point:

- Methyl group on the 17 position: +2 to +3°C; small increase due to increased molecular weight and slight increase in van der Waals interactions.
- Phenyl group at the 21 position: +5 to +8°C; phenyl groups can increase melting point by adding rigidity and π-π stacking interactions between molecules.
- Acetate ester linkage: +2 to +4°C; ester linkages can engage in additional dipole-dipole interactions, though the effect is relatively modest.

Adding these adjustments to the progesterone baseline, we get an estimate for the melting point of this compound.
